Employment Markets Analysis and Research</AuthEnty>         <AuthEnty>Forth, J., National Institute of Economic and Social Research</AuthEnty>         <AuthEnty>Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service</AuthEnty>         <AuthEnty>Policy Studies Institute</AuthEnty>         <AuthEnty>Office for National Statistics</AuthEnty>         <othId>The Policy Studies Institute contributed to the funding of the <i>Workplace Employment Relations Survey</i> (WERS) 2004 study with a grant from the Nuffield Foundation.<br> <br> The Steering Committee for the WERS 2004 study was drawn from representatives of the sponsoring bodies. The members of the Steering Committee are as follows: Grant Fitzner (succeeding Mark Beatson) and Bernard Carter (Department of Trade and Industry (DTI)); Andrew Wareing (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (ACAS)); Paul Rouse (succeeding David Guy) and Professor Keith Whitfield (Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC)); and Malcolm Rigg (succeeding Professor Jim Skea) of the Policy Studies Institute (PSI). John McQueeney, Head of Research in the Employment Markets Analysis and Research (EMAR) section of the DTI, also attended a number of Steering Committee meetings and provided support to the DTI Research Team throughout the course of the study. A number of people assisted in the development of specific question areas, including: six specialist teams of academic experts co-ordinated by Professor Whitfield; academic researchers and lawyers who advised on changing aspects of employment relations legislation; and policy officials within the DTI. The sponsors and research team would like to thank the managers, employees and employee representatives who gave freely of their time to participate in this study. Without their co-operation, the study would not be possible.</othId>       </rspStmt>       <prodStmt>         <copyright>Crown copyright material is reproduced with the permission of the Controller vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/3827bffc-3760-4875-af61-0ef75a718892">WORKS COUNCILS</keyword>         <topcClas>Industrial relations - Employment and labour</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Workplace Employment Relations Survey</i> (WERS) is a national survey of the state of employment relations and working life inside British workplaces. The purpose of WERS has been to provide large-scale, statistically reliable evidence about a broad range of industrial relations and employment practices across almost every sector of the economy in Great Britain. This evidence is collected with several objectives in mind. It aims to provide a mapping of employment relations practices in workplaces across Great Britain, monitor changes in those practices over time, inform policy development and permit an informed assessment of the effects of public policy, and bring about a greater understanding of employment relations as well as of the labour market. The Secure Access version of the WERS data for 1998 and 2004 is held under SN 6712.<br> <br> The Office for National Statistics' (ONS) <i>Annual Respondents Database</i> (ARD) holds responses from one of the most comprehensive surveys undertaken of business organisations in the UK, covering over 100 key economic variables, and approximately two-thirds of the UK economy. Detailed variables for turnover, employment, costs, capital and the derivation of sales and profits are included. The Secure Access version of the ARD data is held under SN 6644.<br> <br> The ONS Virtual Micro-data Laboratory (VML) has created a combined WERS-ARD dataset for workplaces where managers consented to the linking of WERS data with other data sources.  These combined data were constructed by linking observations from the WERS 2004 Survey of Managers to returned financial data from ARD (i.e. the actual responses from the 'dat' files). The linked WERS-ARD data provide a larger sample size for analysis compared with WERS Financial Performance Qustionnaire (FPQ) data. Another advantage is that it is likely that the financial performance data from ARD 2004 would cover a period that is closer to the WERS interview date than the FPQ data. For further information please see the documentation for the study.<br> <br> The VML also combined the WERS 2004 Survey of Managers to previous years of the ARD (2002, 2003).  Researchers may be able to use these older data to explain practices adopted by organisations.<br> <br> Researchers should be aware that if they apply to use these data, they will only receive access to the combined data from the WERS 2004 Survey of Managers dataset and the financial data corresponding to the WERS organisation from the ARD. If researchers wish to access other WERS 2004 data (i.e. the Survey of Employee Representatives, the Survey of Employees, and the FPQ data), they should also apply for SN 6712.<br> <br> Similarly, if researchers require more data from the ARD (such as local unit data), they should also apply for SN 6644.</br></abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The WERS 2004 Survey of Managers contains questions on:<ul><li>recruitment and training</li><li>consultation and communication</li><li>employee representation</li><li>pay determination and payment systems</li><li>grievance and discipline</li><li>equal opportunities</li><li>work-life balance</li><li>health and safety</li><li>flexibility</li><li>establishment performance</li><li>change</li><li>attitudes to work</li></ul>In addition to the main topics covered by the WERS 2004 Survey of Managers, the data include financial data from respondents to the ARD.
